attributes.title: The Impact of Smileys on the Valence of Messages
attributes.description: Investigating the impact of smileys and words on the valence of messages in CMC.

q1.value: The Impact of Smileys on the Valence of Messages

q3.value:
Description: This study investigates whether the perceived valence of messages in text-based computer-mediated communication (CMC) is influenced more strongly by the text of a message or by smileys. 

Background: In face-to-face communication, we use nonverbal cues to express and assess emotions and a lot of research targeted the comparative impact of verbal and non-verbal cues on the interpretation of face-to-face communication. Smileys were developed as a virtual surrogate for facial expressions, but less is know about the comparative importance of smileys and the verbal content of messages. This study seeks to quantify their relative importance.

Purpose: To find out in how strongly smileys influence the perceived valence of messages in CMC and if we, therefore, should not only think about the messages we write to others, but also –or even more – focus on the smileys we send along.

q4.value:
There are two competing positions on the relative importance of verbal (text) and nonverbal (smileys) message components for the interpretation of text-based messages in CMC, arguing that either component is more important for the interpretation of the message. Given the unequivocal nature of previous studies, our hypotheses are non-directional.
To test these hypotheses, the valence of verbal and non-verbal message components will be manipulated orthogonally on three levels: Negative, neutral, and positive valence. This leads to a 3x3 design. Whether verbal or non-verbal components exert a greater effect on the interpretation of a message will be tested in three planned comparisons:

1. Positive text and negative smiley vs. neutral text and neutral smiley: 

Based on the idea that verbal components are more important than nonverbal components, it would be expected that positive texts with negative smileys will be perceived as more positive than neutral messages. Based on the idea that nonverbal components are more important, the opposite would be predicted. 
2. Negative text and positive smiley vs. neutral text and neutral smiley

If verbal components exert a stronger influence, it would be expected that negative texts with positive smileys will be perceived as more negative than neutral messages. If, however, nonverbal components are more important, the messages would be predicted to be perceived more positive than neutral messages. 
3. Positive text and neutral smiley vs neutral text and positive smile:

To test the individual effects of the positive message components in the absence of clear valence on the respective other channel. Based on previous research it is possible that  messages with positive texts and neutral smileys are perceived as more positive than their respective counterparts (neutral texts with positive smileys). Alternatively, it is possible that messages positive smileys and neutral texts will be perceived as more positive.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This experiment has a 3 (Verbal Parts Valence: Positive vs. Neutral vs. Negative) x 3 (Nonverbal Parts Valence: Positive vs. Neutral vs. Negative) within-subject design. The verbal parts are represented by the text messages and the nonverbal parts by the smileys. The dependent variable is the valence of the messages.

q9.value: Based on a pre-test, sets of messages that are identical regarding their general content, but that differ in terms of their valence were generated. To achieve a random allocation of stimuli to participants, it will be randomly determined which message of these sets participants will be presented with during the experiment. Furthermore, which smiley is included in the presented message will be randomized. Finally, the order of the trials will be randomized anew for every participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study will be conducted online using the platform Prolific Academic. We will recruit participants who are fluent in English and who are at least 18 years old. The study will take approximately 5 minutes and participants will receive a small monetary compensation.

q13.value: The target sample size is at least 134 participants.

q14.value:
Previous research so far only investigated the effects of emotion-congruent smileys on perceived message valence and yielded a minimal effect size of dz = 0.45. In the present study, we conservatively estimated that the effect size will be smaller and we used an effect size of dz = 0.30 for our power analysis.

To be able to detect such an effect with a power of (1-β) = 0.80, N = 90 participants are needed. However, in the present study we plan to conduct three planned comparisons to detect effects of this size. For all hypothesis tests to have a power of (1-β) = 0.8, the individual tests need to have a power of (1-β) = 0.93 (0.93^3=0.804) and consequently N = 134 participants are needed.

q15.value: The data collection will be stopped once the desired sample size is reached.

question.value:
Smileys:
We chose three smileys to best represent the three different valences (positive, negative and neutral). This choice is based on the Lisbon Emoji and Emoticon Database (Rodrigues et al., 2018). Their valence scale ranges from 1 (very negative) to 7 (very positive). To convey negativity, we chose the “Pensive Face” (M= 2.4, SD= 1.26) with the Unicode U+1F614. For the neutral emoji, we will present the “Hushed Face” (M= 4.00, SD= 0.84) with the Unicode U+1F62F. To show positivity, we are going to use the “Smiling Face with Open Mouth” (M= 5.78, SD= 1.26) with the Unicode U+1F60A. The smileys actual visualizations are taken from the WhatsApp version 2.19.352.

Verbal Parts:
We developed three parallel versions of messages that are identical regarding their content, but that differ in terms of valence (positive, negative and neutral). The messages were pre-tested in regard to their perceived valence. We compared the valence of each message with their associated smiley (e.g., the valence of the sentence "I'm sad" with the pensive smiley).

The dependent variable will be the perceived valence for each message. Based on a studie on the effect on emoji (Erle & Schmid, 2019), we let participants rate in how far they perceive the messages from 1 (very negative) to 7 (very positive).

The responses to all perceived valence questions will be combined into a single index for all possible combinations: 3 (Verbal Parts Valence: Positive vs. Neutral vs. Negative) x 3 (Nonverbal Parts Valence:  Positive vs. Neutral vs. Negative) .

All analyses will be conducted in SPSS. We will first analyze all data using a 3 (Smiley Valence: Negative, Neutral, Positive) X 3 (Verbal Valence: Negative, Neutral, Positive) repeated-measures ANOVA. The planned comparisons will be tested using non-directional paired-samples t-tests.

q20.value: Valence ratings will be aggregated per cell on the participant level for all analyses.

q21.value: We will use the conventional significance criterion of .05 for all analyses.

q22.value: We do not plan to exclude any participant from the analyses.

q23.value: Missing data will be list-wise deleted.

q24.value: We might compute additional comparisons between the cells of the design to further specify the results of the ANOVA. For example, the negative text and a neutral smiley vs. neutral text and negative smiley.

q2.value: Carla Anne Roos, Kira Choinski, Tom Postmes, Namkje Koudenburg

q3.value: Text-based computer-mediated communication (chat, e-mail etc.) differs from face to face conversations in many aspects. A major difference is the lack of synchronicity in online conversations, which makes interaction relatively less responsive, leads conversation partners to the conclusion that they are ignored and decreases their experienced solidarity towards each other. Therefore, we will investigate the effect of adding back-channel possibilities in the form of interjecting vocalization sounds (as they can be found in face to face conversations) via a keyboard in text-based computer-mediated communication.

q4.value: Increasing responsiveness through adding the possibility for using back-channel signals in text-based online commutation will lead to increased solidarity among interaction partners. This relationship will be mediated by the experience of "feeling heard" in conversation.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Participants are aware of the character of the manipulation but not of its aim.

question.value: Participants will be invited to the lab in duos. They will be seated individually in a cubicle with a computer. An online questionnaire will present them the study information and ask them to give their informed consent. Then they will have 3 different conversations about 3 different topics (holidays, hobbies, and favorite TV shows; in random order) for 5 minutes each. In all 3 conversations, participants will talk about the holidays/hobbies/TV shows of one of them. This participant can only talk via a headset to the other participant. The 3 conversations differ with respect to the way the other participant can talk back (these are the 3 conditions): talk back via a headset, talk back via a text-based online chat, and talk via a text-based online chat as well as an additional keyboard that makes interjecting sounds (like "hmm"). After each conversation, participants will be asked to rate how they felt about the conversation. Duos thus take part in all 3 conditions of which the order is randomized based on a Graeco-Latin square design (see below).

q9.value: The allocation of duos to conditions was based on a Graeco-Latin square design with 36 cells that each represented another combination of conversation topic (3 topics) order and condition (3 conditions) order.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: We are currently collecting data in the lab. We will only start to look at the data after this pre-registration had been submitted.

question.value: Participants were recruited via the first-year psychology student participant pool of the University of Groningen. They were invited to participate via email. They were not allowed to sign up together with a friend and/or if they did not consider themselves proficient in English. Participants received partial course credit for their participation.

q14.value: Based on power calculations and the fact that our design required 36 cells, we decided to recruit one duo per cell.

question.value: The manipulation consists of the way one of the two participants can talk to the other participant that is talking about his/her hobbies/holidays/TV shows via a headset. There are 3 conditions: 1) participant can talk back via a headset, 2) participant can talk back via a text-based online chat, and 3) participant can talk via a text-based online chat as well as an additional keyboard that makes interjecting sounds (like "hmm").

*Conversational flow: This conversation was...: ...good / ...smooth / ...difficult / ...pleasant / ...harmonious

*Solidarity: During this conversation...: ...I liked the other person / ...I felt a sense of belonging with the other person / ...I experienced a sense of unity with the other person / ...I identified with the other person

*Expression clarity: During this conversation, the other person...: ...expressed him/herself clearly / ...expressed him/herself vaguely

*Perceived disinhibition: During this conversation, the other person....: ...thought carefully about how he/she expressed him/herself / ...expressed him/herself politely / ...considered the consequences of what he/she was saying / ...was considerate

*Items related to Feeling heard: 
During this conversation...: ...we misunderstood each other / ...we were on the same wavelength / ......I felt the other person likes me / ...I felt accepted by the other person / ...I felt heard by the other person / ...I felt confident about myself / ...I experienced a sense of failure / Right now, I feel good about myself / ...I could express myself freely / ...I felt like my messages ‘came across’ to the other person / ...the other person took my message into account / ...the other person valued my input to the conversation / ...the other person took me seriously / ...the other person respected what I said/ wrote / ...I envisioned my communication partner when talking to him/ her / ...I felt like I dealt with a very real person / ...I felt like talking to an abstract anonymous person

We will calculate the means of the items used to measure each variable (leaving out items that do not correlate well with the other items composing the variable and thus would make the variable unreliable).

For the measurement of "feeling heard" we will perform exploratory factor analyses.

We will compare the different conditions on the measured variables. We will perform multilevel repeated-measures regression analyses on the data with the lmer function from the lme4 package in R. In all models, condition will be included as fixed effect predictor, group and participant will be included as random effects, and order of conditions will be tested as covariate. We will calculate the means and confidence intervals per condition with the emmeans package in R.

We will calculate (repeated measures) correlations between the dependent variables.

q21.value: p-values and Cohen's d effect sizes.

q22.value: The data will be checked for multivariate outliers, which will be excluded from analyses.

q23.value: NA (we use forced response in the questionnaire)

q24.value:
We want to test the effects of the manipulation on the perception of conversational flow, expression clarity and perceived disinhibiton, because previous studies found indications that these constructs are related to perceived responsiveness.

We will perform an exploratory factor analyses of the "feeling heard" items.

We included a couple of open-ended question about participants' own experiences during the study. We might perform a content analysis on this if it appears interesting.

attributes.title: Mega analysis of functional connectivity markers of trait mindfulness
attributes.description: To look at occurrences of specific states in functional connectivity correlated with trait mindfulness.

summary.value:
We will analyze the following variables using the same strategy as the dynamic connectivity variables described in the first registration:

1) Static connectivity within and between four major brain networks (the default mode network, executive control network, dorsal attention network, and ventral attention network)
2) DFC stability and variability as described in Liu et al., 2018, Human Brain Mapping 39:902-915

registration_responses.summary:
We will analyze the following variables using the same strategy as the dynamic connectivity variables described in the first registration:

1) Static connectivity within and between four major brain networks (the default mode network, executive control network, dorsal attention network, and ventral attention network)
2) DFC stability and variability as described in Liu et al., 2018, Human Brain Mapping 39:902-915

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Between subjects design with 2 factor (sex and culture) and the former 2 levels (female and male),the latter 3(Asian、American、 European)

question.value: Randomly select 64 university students from Europe, North America, Asia and Oceania region as the main sample, try to balance the gender proportion.
Follow the IAT paradigm
We will use a 2*7 ANOVA with both factors between subjects  to analyze our results.

attributes.title: Physiological Responses to Eating Disorder and Social Anxiety Imaginal Fear Scripts
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to investigate physiological arousal while listening to eating disorder and social anxiety fear scripts. Physiological data is collected using Empatica bands, and self-report anxiety is measured using the Subjective Units of Distress Scale (SUDS). We aim to a) test if physiological responses during the fear scripts, as compared to the neutral script, can predict  eating disorder or social anxiety symptom severity, b) if physiological markers of anxiety correlate with self-report anxiety, c) examine if experiential avoidance moderates these relationships.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Physiological Response to Eating Disorder and Social Anxiety Imaginal Fear Scripts

sample.value: Power analyses suggest that with a low estimate of an effect size of .15, 92 participants are needed for adequate power (.80). Data from 110 participants were collected.

analyses.value: Physiological data will be resampled to 4 Hz and preprocessed using Excel and R. Summary statistics (mean, range, and slope) will be calculated for each physiological metric during each script for each participant. Analysis of variance will be conducted using these summary statistics to examine if arousal differed across the three scripts. Summary statistics for the eating disorder script and social anxiety script will be entered into regression analyses and used to predict trait eating disorder and anxiety symptoms respectively.

outliers.value: Bandpass filters will be used to smooth physiological data (EDA) and remove outliers and artifacts. Any physiological data more than 1.5 IQR above the upper quartile or below the lower quartile will also be removed. For trait questionnaires, individuals with EDE-Q global or SIAS straight scores more than 1.5 IQR above the upper quartile or below the lower quartile will be excluded from analyses.

dependent.value: The dependent variables are electrodermal activity, accelerometry, heart rate, and blood volume pulse, which are all measured by the Empatica E4 wristband. Trait social anxiety symptoms and eating disorder symptoms will be measured by the Social Anxiety Interaction Scale (Mattick & Clarke, 1998) and Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire -VI (Fairburn & Beglin, 1994). State anxiety and eating disorder symptoms will be measured by the Brief State Anxiety Measure (Berg et al, 1998) and a modified version of the short form of the Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (Gideon et al., 2016).

conditions.value: This study has six conditions. Each condition is identical, except for the order of the eating disorder, social anxiety, and neutral scripts, which are counterbalanced across the six conditions (1 = neutral, public speaking, weight gain, 2 = neutral, weight gain, public speaking, 3 = weight gain, neutral, public speaking, 4 = weight gain, public speaking, neutral, 5 = public speaking, weight gain, neutral, 6 = public speaking, neutral, weight gain). Participants are assigned randomly to one of these conditions using a random number generator.

hypothesis.value: The primary aim of the current study is to examine if physiological arousal during imaginal exposure fear scripts for social anxiety and eating disorder fears (as compared to a neutral imaginal script) are predictive of eating disorder or anxiety symptom severity. We predict that individuals with high eating disorder symptoms will have elevated physiological arousal during the eating disorder fear script, as compared to the neutral script. Similarly, we predict that individuals with high social anxiety symptoms will have elevated physiological arousal during the social anxiety fear script, as compared to the neutral script.

registration_responses.data: Yes, we already collected the data.
registration_responses.name: Physiological Response to Eating Disorder and Social Anxiety Imaginal Fear Scripts
registration_responses.sample: Power analyses suggest that with a low estimate of an effect size of .15, 92 participants are needed for adequate power (.80). Data from 110 participants were collected.
registration_responses.analyses: Physiological data will be resampled to 4 Hz and preprocessed using Excel and R. Summary statistics (mean, range, and slope) will be calculated for each physiological metric during each script for each participant. Analysis of variance will be conducted using these summary statistics to examine if arousal differed across the three scripts. Summary statistics for the eating disorder script and social anxiety script will be entered into regression analyses and used to predict trait eating disorder and anxiety symptoms respectively.
registration_responses.outliers: Bandpass filters will be used to smooth physiological data (EDA) and remove outliers and artifacts. Any physiological data more than 1.5 IQR above the upper quartile or below the lower quartile will also be removed. For trait questionnaires, individuals with EDE-Q global or SIAS straight scores more than 1.5 IQR above the upper quartile or below the lower quartile will be excluded from analyses.
registration_responses.dependent: The dependent variables are electrodermal activity, accelerometry, heart rate, and blood volume pulse, which are all measured by the Empatica E4 wristband. Trait social anxiety symptoms and eating disorder symptoms will be measured by the Social Anxiety Interaction Scale (Mattick & Clarke, 1998) and Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire -VI (Fairburn & Beglin, 1994). State anxiety and eating disorder symptoms will be measured by the Brief State Anxiety Measure (Berg et al, 1998) and a modified version of the short form of the Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (Gideon et al., 2016).
registration_responses.conditions: This study has six conditions. Each condition is identical, except for the order of the eating disorder, social anxiety, and neutral scripts, which are counterbalanced across the six conditions (1 = neutral, public speaking, weight gain, 2 = neutral, weight gain, public speaking, 3 = weight gain, neutral, public speaking, 4 = weight gain, public speaking, neutral, 5 = public speaking, weight gain, neutral, 6 = public speaking, neutral, weight gain). Participants are assigned randomly to one of these conditions using a random number generator.
registration_responses.hypothesis: The primary aim of the current study is to examine if physiological arousal during imaginal exposure fear scripts for social anxiety and eating disorder fears (as compared to a neutral imaginal script) are predictive of eating disorder or anxiety symptom severity. We predict that individuals with high eating disorder symptoms will have elevated physiological arousal during the eating disorder fear script, as compared to the neutral script. Similarly, we predict that individuals with high social anxiety symptoms will have elevated physiological arousal during the social anxiety fear script, as compared to the neutral script.

attributes.title: Steroidhormon som prediktor
attributes.description: Approximately 70% of breast cancer tumors express estrogen and/or progesterone receptors (ER and PR). For this breast cancer subtype, endocrine treatment represents the mainstay of systemic treatment for both early and metastatic disease. However, a subset of patients will develop endocrine resistance, manifesting as relapse or progression. Side effects of endocrine treatment are well described, including thromboembolic problems, stroke, menopausal symptoms, and tiredness (fatigue). For many who receive systemic therapy the relative benefits may be small and not outweigh the associated costs of side effects. Although recent advances in transcriptomics research have given us a glimpse into the heterogeneity within subgroups, it is not possible to precisely predict a tumor’s response to therapy. Obesity is a risk factor for ER positive breast cancer and correlates with poor prognosis of breast cancer. However, the mechanism of how obesity correlates with endocrine treatment resistance remains unclear. In this project, by use of metabolomics approaches, we will examine steroid hormone metabolomics in breast tumor tissue and serum obtained from a regional breast cancer biobank. We aim to identify novel biomarkers for predicting endocrine treatment resistance and treatment-induced side-effects in both non-obese and obese breast cancer patients. The project will provide novel strategies for appropriate breast cancer treatment and for counteracting negative effects.

q1.value: Steroid hormone metabolism as a novel predictive biomarker for endocrine treatment resistance in breast cancer

q3.value: Approximately 70% of breast cancer tumors express estrogen and/or progesterone receptors (ER and PR). For this breast cancer subtype, endocrine treatment represents the mainstay of systemic treatment for both early and metastatic disease. However, a subset of patients will develop endocrine resistance, manifesting as relapse or progression. Side effects of endocrine treatment are well described, including thromboembolic problems, stroke, menopausal symptoms, and tiredness (fatigue). For many who receive systemic therapy the relative benefits may be small and not outweigh the associated costs of side effects. Although recent advances in transcriptomics research have given us a glimpse into the heterogeneity within subgroups, it is not possible to precisely predict a tumor’s response to therapy. Obesity is a risk factor for ER positive breast cancer and correlates with poor prognosis of breast cancer. However, the mechanism of how obesity correlates with endocrine treatment resistance remains unclear. In this project, by use of metabolomics approaches, we will examine steroid hormone metabolomics in breast tumor tissue and serum obtained from a regional breast cancer biobank. We aim to identify novel biomarkers for predicting endocrine treatment resistance and treatment-induced side-effects in both non-obese and obese breast cancer patients. The project will provide novel strategies for appropriate breast cancer treatment and for counteracting negative effects.

q4.value: Measuring cancer tissue and serum steroid hormone metabolism will facilitate more accurate prediction of endocrine treatment resistance and treatment-induced side-effects in breast cancer patients.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The project is divided into three work packages (WP) as follows: 
WP1: We will include 116 endocrine treatment resistance patients (ER positive) and 116 endocrine treatment non-resistance patients (ER positive). Patients (ER negative, n=116) who are not receiving endocrine treatment will be included as a control.
WP2: Patients  (ER positive and receiving endocrine treatment) from the radiation cohort will be included in this WP. According to BMI, patients will be divided into two groups: overweight and obese (BMI≥25) vs. normal weight (BMI≥20 and less than 25).
WP3: This WP will include serum samples from before radiotherapy (T1), and at two time points after radiotherapy (T2 and T3) of patients (ER positive and receiving endocrine treatment) in the radiation cohort.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will use the Regional Breast Cancer Biobank of Mid-Norway, which consists of fresh-frozen breast cancer tissue from 1000 breast cancer patients obtained during tumor excision, and serum samples from a subcohort of 250 patients receiving radiotherapy (the radiation cohort). Serum from patients in the radiation cohort were collected at six time points: before starting radiotherapy i.e. baseline (T1), immediately after radiotherapy (T2), and thereafter three (T3), six (T4), twelve months (T5), and 7–10 years (T6) after radiotherapy. At each time point patient reported outcomes related to quality of life (QOL) and side effects were collected by questionnaires. After collection, tissue samples were stored in liquid nitrogen, and serum samples in -80 °C. All breast cancer patients in the Regional Biobank were between 18–75 years and were diagnosed with DCIS grade 3 or invasive breast cancer. All patients included in the biobank underwent surgical removal of the tumor, and subsequent treatment regime followed guidelines from the Norwegian Breast Cancer group (NBCG, www.nbcg.no). Seven to 15 years of follow-up information are available for these patients.

q13.value:
For WP1, breast cancer tissue from 116 endocrine treatment resistance patients (ER positive), 116 endocrine treatment non-resistance patients (ER positive), and 116 ER negative patients will be analyzed.
For WP2 and WP3, serum and/or breast cancer tissue samples from patients who received endocrine treatment in the radiation cohort (maximum n=160) will be examined.

q14.value: By use of Stata 15.0 MP2 software, we calculated that 116 patients in each group are needed to detect a difference in 17β-estradiol (E2) concentrations in breast tumor tissue between endocrine treatment resistance and non-resistance breast cancer patients. This is based on mean values of E2 as 0.48 and 0.35 pg/g (highest mean values in pre- and postmenopausal women, respectively), 0.34 and 0.10 pg/g (lowest mean values in pre- and postmenopausal women), and within group variance 0.5 pg/g, with desired statistical power level=0.8, and probability evel=0.05. E2 is the most active form of estrogens and thus its concentration has been used for the calculation.

question.value: Concentrations of 17 steroid hormones, including progestogens, glucocorticoids (such as cortisol), mineralocorticoids, androgens, and estrogens (such as estrone and E2), in serum and breast cancer tissue samples; gene expression levels of estrogen-converting enzymes, including aromatase, steroid sulfatase, 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 (17βHSD1), type 7 (17βHSD7), type 12 (17βHSD12), and steroid receptors (ERα, ERβ, PR, AR, GR, G-protein-coupled receptor (GRP30), and ERα  46kD); levels of serum cytokines (TNF, IL-1α, IL-6, and IL-1β); NMR-based serum metabolomics (112 lipoprotein parameters and 20 serum small molecular weight metabolites); fatigue and cognitive function.
T-test, Mann–Whitney U test, ANOVA, Wilcoxon signed-rank test, Spearman's rank correlation coefficient, and multivariate analysis/machine learning.

registration_responses.q1: Steroid hormone metabolism as a novel predictive biomarker for endocrine treatment resistance in breast cancer
registration_responses.q3: Approximately 70% of breast cancer tumors express estrogen and/or progesterone receptors (ER and PR). For this breast cancer subtype, endocrine treatment represents the mainstay of systemic treatment for both early and metastatic disease. However, a subset of patients will develop endocrine resistance, manifesting as relapse or progression. Side effects of endocrine treatment are well described, including thromboembolic problems, stroke, menopausal symptoms, and tiredness (fatigue). For many who receive systemic therapy the relative benefits may be small and not outweigh the associated costs of side effects. Although recent advances in transcriptomics research have given us a glimpse into the heterogeneity within subgroups, it is not possible to precisely predict a tumor’s response to therapy. Obesity is a risk factor for ER positive breast cancer and correlates with poor prognosis of breast cancer. However, the mechanism of how obesity correlates with endocrine treatment resistance remains unclear. In this project, by use of metabolomics approaches, we will examine steroid hormone metabolomics in breast tumor tissue and serum obtained from a regional breast cancer biobank. We aim to identify novel biomarkers for predicting endocrine treatment resistance and treatment-induced side-effects in both non-obese and obese breast cancer patients. The project will provide novel strategies for appropriate breast cancer treatment and for counteracting negative effects.

attributes.title: Hemiarthroplasty vs Total Hip Arthroplasty for the Management of Displaced Neck of Femur Fractures: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

q1.value: Hemiarthroplasty vs Total Hip Arthroplasty for the Management of Displaced Neck of Femur Fractures: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

q4.value: Displaced femoral neck fractures (DFNF) are common and can be treated with osteosynthesis, hemiarthroplasty (HA), or total hip arthroplasty (THA). There is no consensus as to which intervention is superior in managing DFNF

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Eligible studies met the following PICOS (participants, interventions, comparators, outcomes, and study design) criteria: (1) Population: Patients aged >50yrs with a displaced neck of Femur fracture (Garden Classification III and IV). The fracture was not considered to be pathological. (2) Intervention and comparator: hemiarthroplasty; unipolar or bipolar OR a total hip Arthroplasty. (3) Outcome: The primary outcome was reoperation, all-cause mortality at 30 days and 12 months. Secondary outcomes were dislocation, post-operative infection, Harris Hip Score at 12 months. (4) Study design: RCTs.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: According to PRISMA guidelines, after deleting duplicates, we excluded publications which were not eligible based on titles and abstracts. Then full text articles were reviewed and either excluded based on inclusion/exclusion criteria or included in the analysis.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 1000 participants.

question.value: The primary outcome was reoperation, all-cause mortality at 30 days and 12 months. Secondary outcomes were dislocation, post-operative infection, Harris Hip Score at 12 months.

Direct meta-analysis was performed using a random-effects model to estimate pooled relative risk (RR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs). Heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 test, values greater than 50% indicating substantial heterogeneity. Potential publication bias was evaluated by the funnel plot. We assessed funnel plot asymmetry by using Egger's test, Begg's test and Harbord test. Significant publication bias was defined as p value less than 0.05.
